Name: Screen Test!
Description:
From the Publisher:

And… Action! Movie buffs and trivia junkies can put their knowledge to the test with this interactive DVD movie trivia game. You’ll move around the board and answer questions from clips taken from Metro Goldwyn Mayer (MGM) films. Questions fall into the categories of Star Struck (guess the hidden actor) Take Two (what happens next?) Script Test (finish the famous line) Showtime (general movie trivia) Spotlight (specific movie knowledge) Now Showing (identify the movie) Random (a question from any category) and Outtakes (wild cards). All questions are split into Easy, Medium, and Hard, creating a level playing field for all participants. Will you pass the screen test? The object of the game is to be the first to anwser enough questions correctly to go around the board and get to the end.

Comes with 1 Interactive DVD, 1 Difficulty Level Dice, 1 Game Board, 4 Player Tokens (a clapboard, a reel of film, a movie camera, and a film frame) and Rule Sheet.

Name: Missionary Game 1: Simon kalastajan ihmeelliset seikkailut
Description:
"The Amazing Adventures of Simon the Fisherman" (aka apostle Peter)

This is a religious trivia/party game with roll-and-move mechanics and a deck of trivia/task/event cards.

The game board is a map of Palestine in 33 AD, where the game is set. Each player assumes the role of Simon (Peter) in travelling through the Holy Land in search of three Keys to the Kingdom of Heaven.
 By rolling a 6-sided die, the players move through land, mountain, and water routes. Each city on the map has a face-down counter; these counters represent events and items, including the Keys. When a player lands on a city, they must roll the die to determine whether they must a) turn the counter immediately, b) answer a trivia question, or c) perform a task. The biblical trivia questions are multi-choice (3) and on a correct answer the counter can be turned. The tasks are pantomimes such as "sewing", "smoke getting into eyes" etc. If another player guesses the task correctly, the counter can be turned, and the guesser also gets an extra roll on her turn.

A negative result in the trivia or task finishes the player's turn, but she can remain in the space and try again on the next turn.

If a player lands on a violet space, an event takes place; these are also included in the trivia cards.

The first player to collect three Keys and proceed to the finish ("ship bound for Rome") wins the game.

Name: Tottering Towers
Description:
From the Designer:

"Who just had the big red tower?" Princess Turret or Earl Torquil Tower? Only the player with a good memory and some luck with the dice, will build the highest tower at the end. A memory game for 2-5 high piling players.

Name: Tipayatung
Description:
From the publisher:

Can you finish these famous lines?

Entertainment
‘I want the truth…
Tom Cruise & Jack Nicholson, A few good men

Quotes
‘O Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore…
Juliet, Romeo & Juliet

Your Childhood
‘Mary had a little lamb…
Mary had a little lamb

Music
‘Start spreading the news…
Frank Sinatra; New York, New York

Or are they just on the tip of your tongue?

Get set to play the game that is getting tongues wagging all over the world. Today, you are on center stage! It’s action right from the start as you finish famous lines from movies, TV shows, nursery rhymes, Christmas carols, quotes or proverbs and songs.

Like the name of the game…the next line is often on the Tipayatung. All you have to do is re-live your favorite lines and become the star you were meant to be.

By finishing increasingly more difficult famous lines, you will move through different zones on your journey to the red carpet and center stage. Once there, you’ll have to use all your memory on a tough line.

We guarantee it will be on the Tipayatung!

Play Tipayatung with your family and friends; who knows, it could be the start of something big!

Contents:
- Game Board
- 235 Cards
- Dice
- 6 Game Pieces
- Instructions
- 
Tipaatung is the perfect game for two to six players (more if in teams). Suitable for all ages. There are also some fun game variations inside the box.

Name: Travel Trivia Challenge
Description:
From areyougame.com:

Can you get around the world in 80 days? That’s the challenge for you and your fellow passengers – er, players. You must travel through all 6 continents, answering questions based on each one. Questions might be about the food, languages, landmarks, money, cities, and more. Which Central American country is the original ‘Banana Republic’? Which 60cm object is Thailand’s most sacred figure? The Moors are the dominant ethnic group of which west African country? The answers – Honduras, The Emerald Buddha, and Mauritania. Each correct answer moves you forward on the board, but each time you are asked a question, one day is marked off your timetable. Direction cards might give you added time for your journey (Air traffic control strike – add 2 days to your timetable!) but you might lose time as you pass through Customs. Just like with real travel, you can expect the unexpected and you’re sure to learn things about the world that you never knew before! Who will make it around the world in 80 days or less? Game comes with 4 Wipe Clean Score Cards, 4 Pens, 1 Game Board, 4 Player Tokens, 295 Travel Question Cards, 32 Direction Cards, and 3 Customs Cards.

Name: The Great Safari
Description:
This game is a trick-taking game published in 2000. A variant of hearts, this game has 59 cards divided into 5 suits.
The "endangered suit" acts like the heart suit in "Hearts", but are worth two points per card taken rather than one. In addition, the "Zoo" is a sideboard that the dealer can swap cards after the endangered suit has been declared but before the round starts.
Many of the cards have additional rules text that affect the game in various ways. 
Play four hands (for four players); the player with the lowest score wins.

Name: Age of Steam Expansion: Mississippi Steamboats / Golden Spike
Description:
This Age of Steam Expansion expands the game to Mississippi Steamboats and the Golden Spike.

Age of Steam Expansion: Mississippi Steamboats: This Age of Steam expansion takes place on the great Mississippi River, where Steamboats were used in conjunction with the railroads to quickly and efficiently deliver goods throughout the Midwest. In this 3-6 player map, players compete to build and deliver goods to steamboats which are moving up and down the Mississippi River. Instead of urbanizing towns into cities, players use the Steamboat Building action to build steamboats outside of port cities. Delivering to a steamboat provides players with a 1 income bonus, and goods can be transported from and through steamboats as well. Each turn, the steamboats move a certain number of spaces up or down the river.

Age of Steam Expansion: Golden Spike: This Age of Steam expansion takes place in 1860’s Western USA, where the Union Pacific Railroad and the Central Pacific Railroad raced towards each other in order to complete the first transcontinental railroad system with the Golden Spike. This is a 4-player team-dependent map, with players delivering goods to cities along the main route to build more track towards Promontory; if one side reaches before the other, their opponents are eliminated. The map starts with pre-printed "hidden" track tiles which are revealed each time a good is delivered to a city along the main Sacramento/Promontory/Omaha line. The game ends on the turn that at least one team reaches Promontory; if both teams reach it, victory points are tabulated as usual. If only one team reaches it, the other team's score is reduced to zero (but the winning team still determines each of their score using the traditional manner).

This expansion is professionally designed, printed and mounted on double-sided gameboard, just like the original Age of Steam map.

Name: Minz, Maunz und Bello
Description:
What's going on in the kitchen ?

The little kittens awake on the couch and are hungry. They're looking for their food. It's on the other side of the kitchen, but Bello, the dog is lying on his carpet and keeps an eye on the cup full of food (playing chips). Don't let Bello get you...

A great game for kids. Start with one of five kittens on the couch, roll two dice - one moves the kitten (1-5 + Special BLACK spot for moving the cup of food), the other Bello, the dog. So, Bello is like a community character, each player moves.

Moving is allowed horizontal or vertical only, the same for eating from the cup. When the BLACK spot is on the kitten dice, it allows almost free placement of the cup of food. If Bello the dog, catches one of the kittens, he throws it back to the couch or onto the chair in the corner of the room.

Name: Lost In Space 3D Action Fun Game
Description:
Based on the early 1960's Television Series of the same name. The series starred June Lockhart and Guy Williams as the Robinson family who along with their 3 children (Angela Cartright from The Danny Thomas Show was one of them), Dr. Zachary Smith (the selfish bad guy) and the Robot tried to get back home after their space mission got lost.

The gameboard is 3 levels high and depending on where you land in this Spin and Move game you switch levels.

Name: Get In That Tub
Description: The game involves running a device down a plastic strip. That device would then speak phrases giving reasons for not taking a bath. Stuff like " I can't swim" or "I don't feel good". These excuses would then govern your movement around the board. Object of the game was to get all of your pieces into the plastic bathtub which came with the game.

Name: New Frontier Game
Description: Game from 1962 that is similar to Monopoly and that is critical of the Kennedy Administration. It has deeds, Community Chest Cards called Black Jacks and Chance Cards called High Jacks. The game comes in an envelope and had this comment on the front: "NEW FRONTIER the game no one can win. A reverse twist on a favorite family game"

Name: A Visit To Mother Goose
Description: Listed on the box as a game for little people. This game featured very unique player pieces. Each piece was shaped like a little boy and a little girl either staring up into space or singing. The pieces were made out of some kind of plaster. If handled with some degree of care the pieces lasted, although they did have a tendency to flake their paint.

Name: Petticoat Junction
Description: This game comes from a television show of the same name which showed in the early 1960's. Petticoat Junction starred Bea Benaderit as Kate Bradley who along with her three very pretty daughters, Betty Jo, Bobbie Jo and Billie Jo and there cantankerous Uncle Joe ran the Shady Rest Hotel near Hooterville. This is a simple roll and move race game.

Name: Sub Attack
Description: Object of Sub Attack is to either sink enemy ships or get them safely to port depending on which side you are on. The Fleet Commander spins a spinner to possibly move one of his three ships (blue pawns). The Sub Commander draws one card per turn hoping to get a card showing the letter and color where a ship is located. If this happens, the ship is sunk. Once the Fleet Commander's last ship makes it to port, players switch sides to see how many ships the new Fleet Commander can get back to port. The player who gets the most ships back to port wins.

Name: The Undersea World Game
Description: Game for pre-school children which requires kids to spin a spinner and then match the spin to different fish. (This is not a roll and move game but because their is no choice of spinner I had to chose roll and Move for Mechanics of the game.)

Name: I Dood It
Description: Game based on Red Skelton's radio personalities. The game plays similar to Blitz.

Name: Morbus Terribilis
Description:
Expansion kit of 55 new cards for "Obscura Tempora". Some are of the same kind previously included in the basic set, while others are new: the powerful Cavalry that is strong as two Militias, the Spy to have a look at money in a place or to cards in a hand, the Revolt to steal towns and the Black Plague to destroy them, the Tax Collector to bring money to the Castle and the Bandit to steal it on the way... and a few more.
Morbus Terribilisis meant as a set of optional cards, that experience player can include partly or in block to have a game more suited to their needs and tastes. The cards to steal and destroy towns are anyway strongly suggested to every expert player.

Name: Stage Fright
Description:
Try to guess the four or five highlighted words or phrases by acting out a charades-style performance.  Unlike basic charades, you may use sounds, gestures, pointing and even humming to get the answers right.

Part of the Generations Edition Party Mixers 1950s-1990s box tins.

Name: Quiz Show
Description:
A collection of three outrageous activities designed to test your retro pop-culture knowledge.

Includes 3 games:

1.  Slangshot -- guess a common word from slang clues and phrases.

2.  Spit-It-Out -- describe specific words or phrases without using the word itself.

3.  Triviology -- test your knowledge of the last five decades.

Name: Der kleine Sprechdachs
Description: Der kleine Sprechdachs is a children's game for ages 5+ from Reiner Knizia. Tiles with parts of a story about a little badger have to be memorized to build a coherent story when put together. The player that builds the best story wins. It's a game that teaches language skills and imagination.

Name: Wagon Train
Description:
This game is based on the TV show of the same name that was on from 1957 through 1965. It starred Ward Bond as Major Seth Adams and Robert Horton as Scout Flint McCullough. Bond died of a heart attack in 1960 and was replaced by John McIntire who played Christopher Hale

Wagon Train followed the trials and tribulations of pioneering families as they set out from the East to carve out a new life in the West soon after the American Civil War. For some of the travelers it was a happy ending, but not for all, which only heightened the drama along the way.

The game itself is a simple roll and move game as you try to guide your Wagon Train safely to California. Indian Attacks along the way make the trip difficult.

Name: Jackie Gleason's "And Awa-a-a-a-y We Go!" Game
Description: This game is based on characters created by Jackie Gleason (Ralph Kramden, Joe the Bartender, The Poor Fool and Reginald Van Gleason the 3rd) during his Jackie Gleason Show.

Name: Calgary Stampede: The Game
Description:
This game was developed to relive the experience of the Calgary Stampede.  The interactive game allows players to take part in a wild horse race, chuck wagon races, and frontier casino games.  You can win Stampede raffle draws, and bet your money against other players to build your winnings.  You also get to participate in bull riding, steer wrestling, calf roping and barrel racing.  The one with the most money at the end of the game wins.

Game contents include:

6 playing pieces
4 chuck wagons
8 wild horses
2 spinners
Dice
56 stampede cards
Stampede dollars
Rules

Name: Oz Quiz II
Description:
A light-hearted quiz game about Australia.

Players (represented by stickers stuck on Australian one-cent coins) move around a cartoon map of Australia answering questions in five categories. "Up The Creek" cards can also be drawn, which can have a positive or negative effect on the position of a player.

The game comes in a foam esky (an esky is an Australian Cooler), and was released to celebrate Australia's bicentenary in 1988.

It is the sequel to the very similar Oz Quiz.

Name: A to Z Jr.
Description: A to Z Jr. is  almost exactly like the parent game, A to Z, but with categories that are more child accessible. Everyone gets a board with 25 spaces, one for every letter, except for X and Y which get squashed together. On your turn you role the die, the number you've rolled corresponds to a category that is read to you and then you have 30 seconds to name as many things in that category that you can, covering a letter as you think of words that start with it. First one to cover their entire board wins.
Families: Versions & Editions: Junior Versions of Grown-Up Games

Name: Lady Lovely Locks And The Pixietails: Seek & Peek Game
Description:
Lady Lovely Locks And The Pixietails: Seek & Peek Game is a memory game for children.  It includes paper dolls, a gameboard, a spinner, tokens, disks, and a rule sheet.

Each player picks a paper doll at the beginning of the game.  The paper dolls are each in different colors, has drawings of three Pixietail creatures, and has three cut-out portions wherein Pixietail tokens may be inserted.  The object of the game is to be the first player to collect all three Pixietail tokens to insert in her paper doll and find the Castle disk.

Players take turns with the Spinner to determine the area in the gameboard where she may select face-down Pink disks.  If the other side of the disk she picked up has a Pixietail image of the matching color and design (not yet collected), she takes a similar Pixietail token and inserts it in one of the cut-out sections.  She then returns the disks face-down in the same location in the gameboard where she picked them before.  If a non-matching disk was selected, it is also returned to the same location face-down and play passes to the next player.

If a player's doll collects all three Pixietail tokens, that player then picks only Violet disks in her succeeding turns.  If the Castle is then selected from the Violet disks, that player wins the game.  If the "Duchess RavenWaves" was selected from one of the disks, that player must remove one Pixietail token from her doll.  She then again is demoted to select Pink tokens only until she again completes all her Pixietail tokens.

Name: World of Movies
Description:
A trivia game which tests your knowledge of classic and modern film.

Players move around a board answering questions in various categories. The questions themselves come in four well-produced booklets from which questions are selected at random.

Various cards add to the game play, including "Freeze Frame" cards which require players to act out either a movie title or movie character.

Name: Quartal
Description:
This is an economic game self-published bye Joe Zihlmann from Switzerland.
Winner of the game is the player who first build a trust of 7 companies. The 5 different kind of companies must be part of the winning trust.
Every player starts with 2 companies, fixed by the rules.
The 5 different companies are:
Producer of oil, Producer of metal, Producer of energy, a Factory and a commerce.
Every player has industry-terrain on which he places his company and the elements produced there.
The producers supply the resources, and the factory  builds the end-product with 1 of the three resources.  Then with the commerce you try to sell that product to the market.
In addition, all things can be traded between the players or the market (when available).
The Market is defined with a "wheel", in every round it will be turned/shuffled and shows the buy- and sell-numbers for this turn.
A Turn (all players):
1. Shuffle the market
2. Player produce resources.
3. Buy and/or trade resources with the market and/or the  other players.
4. Production of end-products from the players factories
5. All players try to sell their end-products
6. All players must pay their storage-costs and taxes
7. Buy or sell of companies.

Name: Chathurvimshathi Koshtaka
Description:
This is a game drawn from an old book written in Sanskrit by Harikrishna, son of Venkatram in the late 18th century. It is interesting to read the first stanzas of the book and appreciate the importance he gave to play.

'I hereby describe the organization, structure and rules of this ancient shastra (games), the reason being that there is no such book available and the scholars do not study them. In this book there is a description of several board games, and the intention of this shastra being that people will enhance their brain power by playing them.'

He goes on to conclude the book thus:

I have described the famous games of my time. I do not claim this to be exhaustive, there are several games of various types played in the world and it is physically impossible to compile all of them. I have done my best to compile the most important of my time. ... I, Harikrishna, son of Venkatram was born in Aurangabad in south Maharashtra. I have described in this book many wonderful games and the ways to play them.

It was about the same time that Krishnaraja Wodeyar of Mysore developed and promoted many interesting games.

The game we have here is a simple strategy game described by Harikrishna as a game in 24 squares. We have used the Sanskrit description he has given as the name of the game. Chathurvimshathi Koshtaka simply means 24 boxes or squares.

Contents: game board, two sets of 8 coins each, rule sheet.

Name: Match Ball
Description:
Match Ball is a simulation game of a Tennis match competition. You can emulate your favorite tennis players with this game. I designed the game as a simulation where you can reproduce all the movements and strikes a professional player can do in a match!  You can play as a single player match or doubles.

You have one counter representing you in the court and must move around the field to send the ball to the other side while re-positioning yourself in the best way that you can to cover your side and catch the returning strike from the other player.

You have all the possible strikes in a tennis match that can be done: Serves, Forehand, Backhand, passing shots, lobs, smashes, etc...

The components are:
- Tennis court (Grass)
- Rulebook
- Strike Rule (To be printed in transparency)
- Balls and players counters
- Markers
- Action cards

You will need to provide with 4 dice: 2 color d6, 1 white d6 and a 1d4.

This is my first attempt to design a game. I came up with the idea when creating the geeklist 1:1 scale Sports boardgames that lists games of sports.

Name: Wer War's?
Description:
Use your skills of deduction to identify the person represented by your opponent. By excluding attributes of outward appearance using yes/no-questions you successively get an idea who the other player must be.

Whoever guesses the opponent's name correctly first, wins the game.

Includes the rules, two nearly indestructible plastic playing boards with 24 turnable face cards (so you don't have to remember the attributes already excluded), and a deck of 24 person cards.

Age: 6+

Name: Spanish Fury, Campaign!
Description:
This is module number 2 of the Spanish Fury Renaissance Warfare series. The Dreux campaign of 1562-1563 has been included as a scenario and as such, the rules will use examples from that campaign.

Scale: Each turn represents one week of real time. Note that although an army could march further in the allotted time than the game may allow, most armies were not able to uniformly march about to their heart’s content. Bogged down by the wounded and sick, the need to secure supplies, broken artillery carriages and a rest periods caused most armies to move only when they could, not when they wanted to. Each strength point of troops represents roughly 200-300 men.

The Key: Every game system has a key element that is critical to successful play. It in the 16th supply was the main concern of a commander who had any hope of success. In “Campaign!” supply has been portrayed in Action points. The more action points, the more an army can do. Action points are tallied at the beginning of each turn, and the closer an army is to supply lines and friendly towns, the more it will achieve. Treasury points may be expended to buy action points. Excess action points can under certain circumstances be converted to treasury points.

Components included
Campaign! rules (.doc)
Scenario for the First War of Religion (.doc)
Map for Scenario (.pdf)
Counters (.pdf)
Order of Battle Sheets (.pdf)
Conversion Charts (.pdf)
Component Explanation Chart (.pdf)
The Complete Spanish Fury Miniatures Interface (.doc)

Game FREE to download: http://perfectcaptain.50megs.com/Campaign_Playtest.html

Name: Rescue From Planet Zero
Description: Players move marbles around a three-dimensional board in an attempt to recollect the scattered pieces of a friendly alien's spaceship. The first player to collect all four spaceship parts and return to the cockpit is the winner. Along the way, players will show off their skills at basic math while searching such locations as a volcano, a ziggurat, and a gigantic skeleton.

Name: My Homes and Places
Description:
A therapeutic game for counselors, teachers, and children designed to help kids recognize dangerous situations in supposedly a more fun and less upsetting atmosphere (a game).  It helps kids recognize when someone may approaching them inappropriately, taking advantage of them, or other possible dangers they could encounter.

There are question cards for each of the locations depicted on the board: homes, school, church, courthouse, clubhouse, fantasy castle, and haunted house. For example, at the haunted house, the questions are about scary things, at the church they focus on God and religious differences.

Name: The Wine Connoisseur
Description: A trivia game based on the wine industry; you would need to know quite a bit about wine and the wine industry in order to do well in this game.  It comes in a nice red square box with gold fancy lettering.

Name: Mighty Heroes On The Scene
Description: Mighty Heroes On The Scene   was based on a short lived cartoon series from the times. Join the Strong Man, the Rope Man, Cuckoo Man, Tornado Man and Diaper Man as they battle crime. Villains beware as these Mighty Heroes battle evil everywhere. Roll and Move.

Name: Whooops
Description: This differs from the Whitman Game of the same name produced in the same year (1968). This is a somewhat dexterity game where players need to balance on small plastic bowls. Probably too dangerous for todays market. At the time though Aurora called it a NEW GENERATION GAME.

Name: Ile Jokisen Kapakkakierros
Description:
Ile Jokinen is a Finnish stand-up comedian who created this satiric take on Monopoly. Players are going through pubs and are in constant danger of losing all their money. Luckily every time you pass 'start' the state pays you your unemployment benefit so you can keep on roaming in the pubs. Also the main goal is to be the first to get to a 100% invalidity so you could leave on a pension. 
So there are two ways of wining. Be the first to get the invalidity or the last with some money left.

Name: Center Court College Basketball
Description:
Quick-playing but detailed simulations of college basketball. Instant download, print and play game.

Features Easy to set up & play: Just shuffle the action cards and play. (If you want to keep score, enter the player and team names onto the provided score sheet

All play derived from 100 "action cards": Each card is 2-sided. 3 trips through one side of the cards equals one half of play. This length of playing time varies according to each team's pace rating.

Statistically accurate: Every college team from the 2005-2006 season, along with the players, are rated in every possible statistical category.

ALL college teams represented: Now you can simulate games between Division 1, 2, and 3 teams.

Each team and player rated in several categories: Every statistic you would expect to be covered is here. 2 and 3 point shooting, free throw shooting, rebounding (offensive and defensive), assists, steals, blocks, turnovers, and fouls.

Keep score as you play and compile stats

Even play games between divisions: Match up a division I team against a division II team with simple formulas.

Optional injury system

Exclusive "pace" ratings: One problem I've found with other basketball sims is the lack of realistic scores. Some teams regularly score 100+ points a game, others barely break 60. With the pace system, you will see the scores of your games closely reflect the team's actual output.

Realistic foul system: Another shortcoming with other hoop sims is the lack of realistic foul distribution. Although the highest fouled/fouling players are often correct, the rate at which a team draws fouls is often incorrect. In Center Court, each team draws fouls based on their actual performance.

Game Contents

Complete rule book, including a detailed description of a partial sample game, useful as a tutorial.

Set of action cards, ready for printing

Score sheet

Foul chart

Team cards, divided by division/conference. Each conference is printed on one separate .pdf file, all organized within division.

Name: Pancake!: Women's College Volleyball
Description:
Quick-playing but detailed simulations of womens college volleyball. Instant download, print and play game.

Features Easy to set up & play: Just shuffle the action cards and play. (If you want to keep score, enter the player and team names onto the provided score sheet

All play derived from 100 "action cards": Each card is 2-sided.

Statistically accurate: Every division I college team from the 2005-2006 season, along with the players, are rated in every possible statistical category.

Each team and player rated in several categories: Every statistic you would expect to be covered is here. Service aces, service errors, reception errors, kills, attack errors, blocks (both solo & assisted), block errors, digs, ball handling errors and assists are all accounted for.

Keep score as you play and compile stats.

Optional injury and ejection system

Game Contents
Complete rule book, including a detailed description of a partial sample game, useful as a tutorial.

Set of action cards, ready for printing

Score sheet

Injury and ejection chart

Team cards, divided by conference. Each conference is printed on one separate .pdf file, all organized within division.

Name: Let's Play 14!: College Baseball
Description:
Quick-playing but detailed simulations of college baseball. Instant download, print and play game.

Features Easy to set up & play: Just shuffle the action cards and play. (If you want to keep score, enter the player and team names onto the provided score sheet

All play derived from 100 "action cards": Each card is 2-sided.

Statistically accurate: Every college team from the 2005-2006 season, along with the players, are rated in every major statistical category.

All division I college teams represented.

Each team and player rated in several categories: Every statistic you would expect to be covered is here. Batting average, singles, doubles, triples, home runs, stolen base attempts, stolen base success percentage, opponent's batting average, strikeout & walk frequency and team error ratings are all here.

Keep score as you play and compile stats

All players listed by position, with usage chart included. This enable you to replay games where the players appear in realistic fashion.

Optional injury system

Exclusive "control" ratings: One problem I've found with other baseball sims is the lack of realistic batter/pitcher interaction. With the control system, you will see the great hitter outperform the mediocre pitcher (and vice-versa) in a more consistent manner.

The game engine drives the action. Players will even attempt to steal bases without your input. Of course, you can always call the shots if you prefer.

Game contents
complete rule book, including a detailed description of a partial sample game, useful as a tutorial.

Set of action cards, ready for printing

Score sheet

Out chart & extras chart

Team cards, divided by division/conference. Each conference is printed on one separate .pdf file, all organized within division.

FAQ

What do the team cards look like?

Depending on the roster size, anywhere from about half a page (8-1/2X11") to almost a full page. The tops of the cards are in the team's school colors. All data is organized into color-coded colums for easy reading.

Can I edit the team/player data?

Sure, if you wish to do so. I may release a semi-automated editor for excel if there is any interest in such.

Can I set lineups, call plays, make substitutions, etc?
      You set your lineups and make substitutions. There are a few provisions for calling special plays, such as bunting, hit-and-run, and playing the infield "in". The game being a self-contained simulation, it needs little user input. Having played other basetball games which feature individual player cards, setting of lineups, keeping track of stamina, etc., I wanted something that would yield even more realistic results with less work on the user's part.

Name: Crosse Attack College Lacrosse
Description:
Quick-playing but detailed simulations of college lacrosse. Instant download, print and play game.

Features Easy to set up & play: Just shuffle the action cards and play. (If you want to keep score, enter the player and team names onto the provided score sheet

All play derived from 100 "action cards": Each card is 2-sided.

Statistically accurate: Most college teams from the 2005-2006 season, along with the players, are rated in every major statistical category.

Each team and player rated in several categories: Every statistic you would expect to be covered is here. goals, assists, shooting percentage, ground balls, face-off percentage, penalties, clears, assists, man-up shooting percentage & goalkeeper save percentage are all here.

Keep score as you play and compile stats

Name: Long Tater! Professional Baseball
Description:
Quick-playing but detailed simulations of professional baseball. Instant download, print and play game.

Features Easy to set up & play: Just shuffle the action cards and play. (If you want to keep score, enter the player and team names onto the provided score sheet

All play derived from 100 "action cards": Each card is 2-sided.

Statistically accurate: All big league from the 2005-2006 season, along with the players, are rated in every major statistical category.

Each team and player rated in several categories: Every statistic you would expect to be covered is here, including innovative batter/pitcher match-up ratings, strikeouts, walks, wild pitches, balks, hit batsmen, singles, doubles, triples, homers, double plays, errors and more.

Keep score as you play and compile stats. The game can handle most managerial situations if you wish. Of course you can still call the shots if you wish. Have the game engine determine when to steal a base while calling for the hit-and-run yourself.

Name: Invite Womens College Golf
Description:
Quick-playing but detailed simulations of college golf. Instant download, print and play game.

Features Easy to set up & play: Just shuffle the action cards and play. (If you want to keep score, enter the player and team names onto the provided score sheet

All play derived from 100 "action cards": Each card is 2-sided.

Statistically accurate: All squads from the 2005-2006 season, along with the players, are rated by the use of every single match score..

Weather system alters player performances, from gusting wind to drizzling rain and hard greens.

Events chart can alter certain players scores. Every woman golfer who appeared in at least 3 matches is represented. The game plays quickly, but with realistic results. Full tournaments of 3 rounds can be simulated in about an hour. Set your starting lineup and tee off. Accept the invite!

Name: The New Howard H. Jones Collegiate Football Game
Description:
This football game was created By Howard H. Jones who was not only the President of the Municipal Service Corp., Ltd. which produced the game but also the Coach of the Southern California 1931 National Championship team.

Kickoff's, Field Goals  and Punts use a special mechanical device that kicks the ball.

On Offense the player chooses one of 8 possible plays to call and then spins an arrow which stops on letters. Then the defense spins the arrow and gets a letter result. The result of these two spins determines what happens to the ball.

As an aside here is a couple of words of advice from the head coach about football strategy from the times.

Question: With 4th down and a foot in a scoreless tie shall I attempt to make the foot or punt the ball. ANSWER from COACH: You should have really punted on 3rd down. By all means PUNT, failure to make a 1st down would put your opponent in good position to score.

Question: Is it safe to attempt a forward pass while still within ones own 40 yard line. ANSWER: Usually it isn't. There are times when this play is worked with success. One can only depend on ones own judgment.

Question: With the score 9 to 7 against me with 3 minutes to go in the game and the ball on my opponents 28 yard line what play would you use?  ANSWER: A wide end run to get the ball in the center of the field on 1st down and then I would try a place kick on 2nd down

Name: Knowwhere
Description:
From the Publishers website:

Knowwhere is an educational card game that seeks to provide both fun and learning to children and adults alike. Based upon a traditional "pairs" format, the aim of the game is to match country to capital city, but can be played on many levels to suit all ages.

Knowwhere is made up of 37 Country Cards, 37 Capital Cards, and 4 Cards which have the same Country and Capital name and count as a pair in their own right. Each pack is also supplied with 6 Answer Cards

Name: Wise Up
Description:
From the Publisher's Website:

The action packed board game helping children understand and face the challenging dilemmas of everyday life in a fun but responsible way. Topics include stranger danger, road safety, bullying, racism, first aid and many more.

For ages 5 and up.

Name: Alcañiz 1809, Maria 1809, Castalla 1813
Description:
Three battles in Spain. System : La sombra del Aguila -- includes the advanced rules.

The English language rules were translated for Paper Wars in 1995.

Mounted counters.

Game System:
- scale = 250m/hex; 
- time = 20 min/GT; 
- strength = battaillons (inf), regiments (cav), batteries (art).
Families: Series: The Shadow of the Eagle

Name: Queens' Gambit: Italy, 1742-48
Description:
Queens' Gambit: Italy 1742-48 - Volume IV in the Lace Wars series

Queens' Gambit (QG) is the fourth volume of Red Sash Games Lace Wars series. Like its predecessors, Sport of Kings, Cockpit of Europe and Charlie's Year, it examines the War of the Austrian Succession at an operational level. Italy is the stage this time. Physically isolated from the titanic struggles in Germany and the Low Countries, Italy was anything but a backwater: successes and failures here had an important impact on the war as a whole. The war for Italy opened at the beginning of 1742. The Spanish Crown, after lengthy preparations, successfully invaded Italy by sea, bent on acquiring a duchy for the Queen's son, Don Felipe, and on reclaiming Spanish dominance in the region. Distracted by events elsewhere, the Habsburgs and their British allies were unable to prevent this move, but soon rebounded, drawing as a reluctant partner the pre-eminent local power, Piedmont-Sardinia, and its Frederician-like ruler, Charles Emmanuel of the House of Savoy.

QG can accommodate up to four players, though it is easily played with two, and can even be played solitaire. The four sides are Bourbon France, Bourbon Spain, the Habsburg Empire, and Savoy (Piedmont-Sardinia). Also available are the forces of Genoa, Modena, Venice, Naples, and some pesky Royal Marines. Other territories, like the Papal States, wield influence rather than the sword.

A game on the War of Austrian Succession in Italy. In the same serie as Sport of Kings, Cockpit of Europe and Charlie's Year (Lace Wars). Both DTP and mounted versions exist.

Map scale is 8.5 miles per hex. Most units are brigades. Units are rated for Strength (in battalions),

- 6 maps
- Three books
- Charts
- 1200 counters in 10 counter sheets (incl. markers)
Families: History: War of the Austrian Succession

Name: Spanish Fury, Sail!
Description:
Naval Warfare, 1560-1603

Now then, what's Sail!  like anyway?

We were after something more than fast play, but much less than complexity. These rules were originally meant for each model to represent more than one ship, and you can still play it that way. However at one-to-one it works best. As is our way, we wanted players to feel like they were playing their favorite navies. The tactics of one fleet will not work for another.

Which nations are represented?

We have decided to start out with Spanish/Portuguese, English and Dutch navies. French and Hansards are provided for to a lesser extent. Other navies, particularly Danish and Swedish, will be the subjects of later supplements.

How many ships can you play a side?

You can have from one ship per side up to forty, and still have a good time. As you'll see below, the game is intriguingly uncomplicated without being "fast play", meaning no engagement is too small, and the larger battles can still be played without overly bogging down. We suggest each player control no more than 15-20 ships each, so with several players per side (and a big enough board) you could re-fight the whole Armada campaign!

Does it take long to play?

We finished a game with 15 ships per side in less than 90 minutes. Yet we do not consider
these rules "fast play" (in other words, sacrificing too much realism for speed)

Do I have to write anything down?

Now you know how the Captain feels about record keeping..... Pen and paper are not required.

Name: Laramie
Description: The game Laramie was based on the television show of the same name that aired between 1959 and 1962. That show starred John Smith as Slim Sherman, Robert Fuller (eventually of Wagon Train fame) as Jess Harper , Hoagy Carmichael as Jonesy and Spring Byington as Miss Daisy. The show was about two brothers and a drifter trying to run a stage coach stop for the Greater Central Overland Mail Company. The game itself is a simple roll and move game with the object being to get the mail through while overcoming obstacles like Indians and Bandits.

Name: The Atonement: Miracle of Christ's Love
Description: The Atonement: Miracle of Christ’s Love from the Latter Day Saints is a captivating activity game involving many aspects of the Plan of Salvation, including choices, sins, good works, ordinances, spiritual gifts, trials, missionary work and temple work.  Players interact in both Earth Life and in the Spirit World and are eventually judged and assigned to a degree of glory. The game was created by Kathryn Matthews over a period of 12 years.  Her son, Jonathan, suffered from kidney failure at a young age which prompted her to donate her own kidney to him.  Over the following ten years, Jonathan suffered deteriorating health and required constant tending until his death in 1999.  It was during this difficult time that Kathryn found comfort in learning the doctrines of the Plan of Salvation and spending time creating a learning activity that teaches about the joy it brings.

Name: Monopoly: Edinburgh
Description:
Another city Monopoly edition to appeal to tourists and locals!

From box:

"Monopoly, the great property trading board game finds its home in Scotland's capital city.  You can play the classic game with the street names, landmarks and locations which give the city its distinctive character.
From Edinburgh Castle to the Palace of Holyrood House, the Royal Mile descends the sloping rocky ridge on which the medieval Old Town of Edinburgh was built.
Scotland's story reverberates through every close and wynd on the historic thoroughfare.  Each summer provides a dramatic backdrop to the annual Edinburgh International Festival, the world's largest arts and cultural extravaganza.
The cramped and irregular architecture of the 'Old Town' stands in contrast to the neat symmetry sought by the planners of the eighteenth century 'New Town'.
The city's cherished open spaces, the imposing heights of Arthur's Seat and the gentle panorama of the Pentland Hills combine to create a sense of spaciousness rare in urban areas."

Not that the above tells you anything about the game!

In addition to local streets, most properties have been branded/sponsored by appropriate businesses (for example, Jenners on Princes Street).

Name: Mischief Mini Golf Card Game
Description:
Mischief makes miniature golf even more fun!

In Mischief, players are dealt 3 cards at the start of a round of Mini Golf. While playing a real-world round of mini golf, players will have opportunities to play cards on themselves or their opponents. These cards enhance the play of the game creating a fun and competitive round of Mini Golf like you've never experienced before. Every hole players draw more cards, so there are always 3 cards in your hand to choose from. Because of the wide variety of cards included, no two games are ever quite the same. As an added bonus, Mischief can also be used as a standard deck of playing cards.

Mischief also includes between hole mini-games to help pass the time in line.
Families: Admin: Outside the Scope of BGG

Name: Shhh!... Mom's Asleep
Description:
It's afternoon and Mom is having a nap with Baby.

She has left a list of chores for us to do. We want to help Mom out. There are many useful tools around the house we must match to their chores.

Careful, though, not to wake Mom & Baby before the chores get done. Maybe the dog barks, maybe someone knocks over pots and pans, maybe we kids get into a noisy fight... We have to figure out how to deal with these events.

Expect story-telling, discussion, imagination, logic, working as a team and learning about practical things around the Home. And learning to be good is important as well!
 Contents: 
1 gameboard 
36 cards 
rules

Name: The Birds of Summer
Description:
Players are parent birds trying to save their baby birds from predators such as hawks and cats. The cards provide 6 places for nests, 6 birds, 6 predators and 6 kinds of food.

All the action takes place on the Neighborhood Chart. Predator dangers are placed near the neighborhood. Places to make nests are played first, then nests, then food for each nest, which attracts a predator. Will we, the parent birds, be able to chase away the predator? Clever play will make all the difference, as we talk over our plans and make careful choices, with each player making an important contribution.

This game is exciting and educational: memory, math and problem solving skills are nurtured as well.
 Contents: 
35 cards 
neighborhood chart 
rules

Name: Let's Go Hiking
Description:
Armed with just cameras, binoculars & some other equipment, we leave our camp & hike into the park to learn about wildlife. We may be surprised what we learn about ourselves as well.

Our goal is to bring back as many photographs as we can of the animals we track and end up at the guest lodge for refreshment. We will try to leave the park as undisturbed as possible, maybe leaving only our footprints behind. Before the game ends, we will learn about the wisdom of the woods, its dangers, its plants (both good & nasty), its creatures, large & small, AND ways of tracking that use sound, scent & sight to best advantage. This will be a shared, group experience! 
 Contents: 
1 gameboard 
1 hikers pawn 
1 die 
55 cards (consisting of 19 problems, 12 photographs of animals/tracks, 13 solutions, and 21 movements)
rules

Name: Seekers of the Sacred Icons
Description:
Barbarians have stolen four containers each with a special parchment revealing the secrets to gaining Truth, Beauty, Compassion and Freedom. However, each container cannot be opened without knowing the secret code.

Each code is different and kept by the Ten Guardians of the Codes. The ruthless, brutal barbarians have captured and imprisoned the Ten Guardians in the vain hope of extracting the secret codes...

The Sacred Icons and Guardians are somewhere in the Walled City controlled by the barbarians. We, the Seekers, enter this city in search of the Sacred Icons and the Guardians so that the Icons can be restored to their four spiritual power centers.

The task will be difficult and not for the faint-hearted. Locked doors and nasty barbarians await as we quietly do our search.
 Contents: 
1 gameboard 
4 pawns 
4 spiritual power indicators 
4 seeker cards 
9 locked doors 
11 barbarians 
4 icon containers 
10 guardians of the codes 
8 keys 
rules

Name: Stop the Presses!
Description:
We need to bring in enough Stories, illustrated with photos and cartoons and advertising contracts to meet the printing costs and staff payroll. If we can't meet these combined costs, then it is a case of STOP THE PRESSES! There isn't enough money to print our beloved Weekly Illuminator.

Our revenues come from reader circulation and advertising. We have a team of fine reporters chasing down stories, an advertising representative working magic on securing contracts, a photographer with an eye for photos that sell, a cartoonist who knows how to stir up controversy to add readership and, last, but not least, an editor with a warm, soft heart and steel-like brain (or is it the other way around?) -- as well as a steady hand for guiding our newspaper through thorny issues such as the libel suit, the press union's demand for a pay raise, people offended by our cartoons... imagine their nerve telling us what to publish and not to publish!?!

Contents: 
1 gameboard 
1 reporter pawn 
1 press time marker 
1 die 
55 cards: 
10 staff 
2 cartoons 
1 comic page 
6 photos 
6 issues 
12 ad contracts 
18 assorted stories 
rules

Name: Seek
Description:
From the rulebook:
You have heard of a man called Jesus of Nazareth who is performing many amazing miracles; you want to find Him to become one of His disciples.  The object of this game is to seek for Jesus in order to answer three questions: (1) Where is He? (2) What is He doing? (3) Who is with Him?  The first player to answer these three questions correctly wins the game.

Name: Mother
Description:
(from publisher's website)

Was your mother's love measured by the circumference of her meatballs? Or was it stored in a Tupperware container to keep for a later date? Whether she was perfectly doting or passive aggressive, here's your chance to have the mother you never had or to relive your happy childhood. If you've ever had a mother, you need to play this game. Because whether you win or lose, it's guaranteed to be more fun than a barrel full of...well...mothers.

By answering a series of pop culture, pop psychology, history, trivia, and other ridiculously humorous mother-related questions like "Which sandwich most effectively alleviates guilt; turkey on whole wheat or corned beef on rye?" players move ahead one square. Or by role playing and acting out commands such as "Go 1 minute without showing any emotions" players move ahead 2 squares to move around the board and be the first one "in the will", while trying to avoid taking a "guilt trip", going to "therapy", doing a stint in "jail/rehab" or spending time in a "monastery/bunker".

Name: Stratagame
Description:
From Website http://www.stratagame.org (now defunct)
 The fate of the world is at stake !

Six major powers compete for control over world resources as alliances rise and fall, and armies sweep over the continent. Stratagame is as much about skillful diplomacy as is it about chess-like strategic know-how. The player who in the end owns most of the continent’s resources wins this game of epic adventure.

Stratagame is a strategy game in which 2 to 6 players try to capture the continent’s resources. It is played on a chessboard roughly representing Europe. There are no countries or clearly defined territories in Stratagame. It has no preset historical framework and no realistic pretensions, therefore it is not a wargame or a simulation game. Stratagame combines the mechanics of games like chess with modern strategy principles. Compared to other games in its category, Stratagame has been designed to be simple and easily understood. There are no overly complex or difficult rules and the manual has only 6 pages of rules. However, as in chess, the simplicity of the rules does not guarantee an easy mastery of the game. Stratagame is generally played in 2 to 4 hours, depending on the number of players and strategies involved.

Stratagame contains 6 armies of different colours each composed of 52 playing pieces. As in chess, when a playing piece tries to enter a square already occupied by an enemy piece, a combat occurs. Each playing piece has a Strength of 1 to 5. A playing piece’s Strength determines the number of dice it rolls during combat. The piece obtaining the highest result on the dice wins the combat. As per other chess-like games, Stratagame can also be played without dice.

Name: Battle: The American Civil War
Description: This is an updated version of the game originally published by Yaquinto Publications in 1979 and out of print since 1984. It is an abstract war game for novices and veteran gamers alike, using variable “battlefield tiles” and wooden playing pieces. Unit combat values depend on the terrain they occupy and change as they are moved. The game depends entirely on skill, with no dice used.

Name: Picture This?
Description:
Your favorite celebrities from Hollywood TV and sport together with global places events and people that have shaped our world in a fast paced visual trivia board game with a twist. Even if you think you know Kylie Minogue from Jessica Simpson and Lleyton Hewitt from Andy Roddick - do you have knowledge to answer the remaining trivia to win the card The excitement builds with the Challenge and All Play This rounds - gamble your cards and challenge your opponents This fast paced game lasts between 40-60 minutes with the ultimate Double or Quits finale.

One answers as many questions as possible to collect cards, the player with the most cards wins at the end. One can use 1 or 2 dice to regulate the playing time. In his turn a player rolls the die and moves his pawn, then he must answer all three questions from a card in the category reached. One has one try for each question, for the third correctly answered question one receives the card, otherwise another player gets a chance. Creative squares demand drawing or pantomime, on poker squares one can bet cards against another player, the first one to answer a 3rd question correctly wins the bet cards from the opponent. On the Double square at the end of the game one has the chance to double the number of cards

Name: Draw-Bridge
Description:
An interesting 2-player Bridge game manufactured in polished wood by Chas Goodall & Sons Ltd, Camden Works London at some time in the early 20th Century. The main component of the game is a pair of stepped wooden slabs with 13 slots cut into them at 45 degrees so 2 dummy hands can be stood up at that angle, the slabs can then be placed on the table so one player can see the cards, but opponent can't.  The actual rules for this 2-player version of Bridge are on the back of the wooden steps.

Although the actual date of manufacture has not been established, the game carries a patent dated 1905.

Name: SLAM!
Description:
A 2 player trick-taking card game using a deck of 32 cards.

This was Sid Sackson's first published game.  He self published it in 1951.  He subsequently included it in his book A Gamut of Games.

Name: Space Tivitz
Description:
Educational Math board game that uses checkers type movement.  The playing pieces called a "Tivit" are 6 sided dice with each side having a symbol and numerical value.  The 2 players race to reach the 9 planets.  Each Planet has a mathematical operation(addition, subtraction, multiplication or division).   A players score is the value of their tivit adjusted for the math operation for each tivit that lands on a planet.

The game includes 30 different paper boards with varying degrees of difficulty.  For ages 8 and up.

Name: Arvaa Nimi
Description:
The "Guess the Name Game"

There's a plastic-coated, metallic gameboard with the alphabet printed on both sides, and two sets of small magnetic frames, each with 7 black and 3 red, as well as eight small decks of cards, which are boys' and girls' names divided in four levels of difficulty.

The game can be played by either 2 players or 2 teams of roughly equal capacity; therefore, there is no upper limit to the number of players except practicality. First, players must decide if they play a certain level of difficulty, certain gender, or if they want a random game with all the cards shuffled together. The board is set upright between the two teams on two plastic feet and then both teams reveal a card for themselves only. They must then use the magnetic frames to mark all the letters appearing in the name - red frames are used to denote letters that appear in the name more than once.

The gameboard is then turned the other way around and now the actual game begins, with the two teams competing in who is the quickest to guess the other team's name. (It must be agreed in advance whether all names that fit the given letters are allowed, or only the particular one in the card.)

The winning team gets the card as a point, and the first team to get 10 cards is the winner.

Name: Junnutonni
Description:
1985-2005 in Finnish television there was a really popular show called Kymppitonni (~Tenthousand). In the show there were always five celebrity competitors who in turn got a word that was meant to be an answer to a question. The competitor now had to come up with an ideal question. If no-one else knew the answer or everybody else knew the answer the competitor would have got minus points for making a too hard or simple question. If only one of the others came up with the right answer both of these competitors would have got the maximum points and so on.

In early nineties another show, Junnutonni (~Juniorthousand), was created to satisfy the needs of younger audience. Words were easier and a boardgame was also created a bit later.

Name: Bullwinkle Travel Adventure Game
Description: Simple roll and move game based on cartoon show from the times. The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show featured Rocket "Rocky" J. Squirrel, a flying squirrel, and his best friend Bullwinkle J. Moose, a dim-witted but good-natured moose who both lived in Frostbite Falls, Minnesota. The scheming villains in most episodes were the fiendish, but inept, agents of the fictitious nation of Pottsylvania: Boris Badenov and Natasha Fatale.
Families: TV Shows: The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show

Name: Wehrschach
Description:
Wehrschach, also called Tak-Tik, was published by the nationalsocialist German magazine "Die Wehrmacht" in 1937/1938. It brought modern pieces to a Chess-like board: Infantry, Armor, Fighter and Bomber planes, Artillery, and a unique piece (the 'Hauptfigur'), styled like an eagle, which abstractly represented the government, industrial base, and morale of the state.

On an Board with 11 x 11 squares you play a chess-like game with 18 pieces per player, for instance the "Jagdflieger" or the "Panzerkampfwagen", all 3D and of Bakelite. These can move only vertical or horizontal, but a different number of squares, with the exception of the "Panzerkampfwagen", which might also move like the knight in chess, but without jumping over other pieces.

To capture an enemy piece you need to threaten it with two of your pieces instead of just one.

The board is divided through diagonal lines (the main road and the river) and two more lines crossing the 3rd and 9th row indicating walls and two lake tiles which block all movement except for the planes.

Gameplay was more or less like chess, but with some special rules for the different figures. There were several ways to win: capture of the Hauptfigur; destruction of all enemy Infantry; reduction of his fighting power; occupation of his homeland; etc. This, coupled with the two-to-one capture rules makes it more challenging (and rewarding!) than Chess.

Name: Word-O-Matic
Description:
Word-O-Matic "The Competitive Word Building Game"

From the Box-

"Race Against Time...Develop More Words Than Your Opponents."

"Challenge Yourself...Challenge Others."

"Different Letter Combination With Every Spin of WORD-O-MATIC."

You pull the handle on the word-o-matic machine (requires 1 "C" battery) and the wheels start moving.  You then hit the 5 buttons on the front of the word-o-matic to stop the wheels.  You have until the sand timer runs out to make as many 4 - 7 letter words as you can.

Name: Shrinkwords
Description:
Given a wacky story as context, fill in each blank by removing a letter from the previous word and rearranging what is left.

Example from box:
To bring off this party trick requires great PANACHE. You have to eat a XXXXXX while balanacing a XXXXX nut on the XXXX of your neck and a XXX on your nose.

With the answers being canape, pecan, nape and pea.

Name: The Snowman Game
Description:
The object of this game is to be the first player to arrive back in the garden with a present from the Snowman Party. Before you can do this, you'll have to complete the rest of his costume by collecting 4 cards that represent the building of the Snowman - the body, the head, the face and the scarf plus hat.
Contents:

Instruction Sheet

16x Building Cards with 4x cards in each set of body, head, face, hat and scarf

4x Present Cards

Dice and Shaker

4x Snowmen Pieces

Counters

Deluxe Playing Board

Name: What's That Song?
Description: What's That Song is a lively and entertaining game, featuring over 700 song titles, for two or more players or teams. Spin the needle to determine the decade. Select a song title from that decade 50s 60s 70s 80s or old faves and sing a clue from the song title. Singing, facial expressions and body movements are all encouraged to help your team guess the song title. Points are awarded for the correct answer.

Name: Strawberry Shortcake Game Basket
Description: A collection of four games in one with a Strawberry Shortcake theme: Memory, Lotto, Dominoes, and Bingo.

Name: Self-Concept Game
Description: This is a game used to help kids build their self-esteem.  Developed by a PhD in kids psychology.

Name: Shift
Description: You bid cards and play similarly to a trump style game.  the high trump card overrides all others and takes the trick.  that is until the Shift card is played, then the low trump takes the trick.  Timing the shift to the low trump is key to winning.

Name: Rukshuk: Edition 2
Description:
Rukshuk - the world's original game of rock-balancing is back with more edge-of-the-seat fun!

RUKSHUK - Edition 2 features all new Game Rocks and cool new RUKSHUK formations guaranteed to challenge and thrill!

Race against the clock to build the different Rukshuk formations and score as many points as you can. Skill, luck and strategy determine who will score the most points and win!

1 to 5 players draw 7 game rocks each then turn over a card to reveal a RUKSHUK formation. Regular and bonus points are scored by building as much of the formation as possible within the time limit. If a formation topples, it must be rebuilt before time runs out! Points are scored for the balanced rocks at the end of the time limit, with additional points for three-of-a-kind and completion. Choose to play some or all formations in a game, and the player with the highest points wins.

Re-implements:

    Rukshuk

Name: Pack and Stack
Description:
This is a simple game of loading semi-trucks... players each have a truck "frame" in which they place pieces (rectangles & squares) based on the roll of two dice. Certain types of pieces can not be immediately placed but are stored to the side, waiting for the right "hole" in the back of your truck. The first player to fill their truck wins; if the pieces run out without any player filling their truck, the player with the least empty space wins.

Ages 6-12

Name: Finger On The Trigger!
Description:
The quick thinking 'Electronic' name game. Be the first to hit the button, and say a name that fits the card and letter. The fastest player keeps the card and the most cards wins the game! Includes one electronic unit with lights and sounds and 30 cards.

—description from the publisher

In this game with an electronic game board, the players need to figure out words in different categories the fastest. Ranging from movies and artists to body parts and flowers, this game challenges to think fast and react even faster. 
The electronic game board says a letter out loud, and the fastest player to press their button gets to say a word in that category starting with that letter. The player with the most wins in the end wins.

—user summary

Name: Chaingun
Description:
As far as I know this is the only set of miniatures rules specifically dealing with air-to-air combat between helicopters, though air-to-ground and ground-to-air combat is also covered. The rules are intended for use with 1/300th scale miniatures and the other game scales are as follows:

1 model = 1 aircraft, vehicle, infantry platoon
1 turn = 10-15 seconds
1" = 100 yards

Each turn the player picks the speed and altitude for each helicopter they control, which determines how far they will move, how much they may turn and their chance of crashing into the ground, if flying too fast and too low. Combat is resolved using the usual die rolls and tables, with the different makes of helicopter being able to take different amounts of damage before they are eliminated.

The majority of the rule book is taken up with the helicopter data sheets and there are no less than 46 of them. Ground elements are detailed generically. There are also five sample scenarios.

Name: Cranium Wacky Words
Description:
With Cranium Wacky Words, your family has the last word on outrageous fun!

Ever tried Grandma's recipe for stinky socks? Or read a weather report about jellyfish blowing in from the east?

From horoscopes to doctors' notes to book reports and vacation postcards, Wacky Words gets players filling in the blanks with laugh-out-loud results!

Name: Count Across
Description:
From the Publisher's website:

Test your math and strategy skills against the luck of the roll. Simply roll the dice and add or multiply the numbers. Then claim a space on the number board. First player to connect four in a row wins. Learning math has never been such a fun challenge for both kids AND adults! Ages 6 & up.

Name: Express It Guess It
Description:
From the Publisher's website:

Its the game where you get to express all kinds of feelings by drawing, charading and talking. Can you draw the word confused? Or act out the word sneaky? Can you say the tongue twister Peter Piper and make other people guess the word forgetful? Every correct guess you move ahead a space in the race to the finish.

Name: Tactex
Description: Tactex is a hexagonal version of Piet Hein's classic TacTix which was a two-dimensional generalization of Nim. In Tac Tix, players take turns removing pieces away from a rectangular grid. In Tactex, pieces are placed on a five by five by five hexagonally-tiled field and are removed from one of the nine vertical columns or eighteen diagonal rows.

Name: Ximo
Description: The game of Ximo is a set of variants of the traditional game Nim, where you try to be the last player able to pick a marker up off the table.  It comes with a cloth bag and a supply of wooden disks with various symbols on them.  The symbols place restrictions on what disks may be picked up, allowing for strategic plays.  There are several variations included.

Name: Battleship Missile Strike
Description:
From the game package:
How will you do in the line of fire?
Seek and destroy your opponent's ships in this all-out, no holds barred dice duel.  Secretly set up your tokens on your battlefield and brace yourself as your opponent attacks.  Was it a hit or miss?  Fire back and see if you can be the first player to sink all of your opponent's ships, and win!

From Erik Arneson's website:
Players first play tokens (numbered 3 to 11) on each of their five ships, making sure to put them in order from lowest to highest -- although duplicate numbers are allowed. To attack, each player rolls three dice and chooses two. They place those two dice next to a token, and if the total equals the value of the token, a hit is scored. Rolls of 2 and 12 are always hits. Unfortunately, this clever Battleship-based dice game is not very easy to find. Your best bet is to look in drug stores and grocery stores.

Name: Multilingo
Description: Multilingo can be played in English, French, Italian or Spanish ­ or in any combination of the four. Players spell words using letter tiles. The game gets kicked up several notches as players "borrow" other players' words to create new ones. Ingenuity, a keen eye and an array of techniques are used to create and recreate words. Will you be borrowing the most valuable words? Handicap levels the field so that anyone can play, even sophisticated word-smiths can play with children just learning to read.

Name: The Brownie Game
Description:
Designed in conjunction with the Girl Guides Association.

"Part of the fun of being in the Brownie organization is trying to collect badges by achieving efficiency in a number of categories. The object of this game is just the same. Players have to collect interest badges by successfully answering questions on the subjects chosen."

Players try to collect five badges and be the first to collect the trefoil badge. Players roll a dice to move around the board. Upon landing on an interest badge space, they must choose one of the tiles from a face down selection. Most of the tiles represent Brownie badges in several categories, a few are hazardous events, and one shows the trefoil, crucial to winning the game. To collect a badge of the revealed category, the player must answer a trivia question relating to the category. Badges are available in the following categories:

Animal Lover; Artist; Book Lover; Brownie Friendship; Cook; Collector; Conservation; Craft; Discoverer; First Aid; House Orderly; Music Lover; Pony Rider; Rambler; Safety in the Home.

If the question is answered correctly, the badge tile is placed on the player's arm card (representing the badge being sewn onto the player's shirt sleeve). If it is answered incorrectly, the tile is turned face down again. When a player has collected five badges on her arm card, she must try to find the Trefoil badge from the face down selection in order to win the game.

Players can steal badges from Brownies who trespass on another player's campsite. Bonus badges can be won by landing on toadstool spaces and answering a general knowledge question. The game can end prematurely if too many Brown Owl spaces are landed on.

Name: Gauntlet
Description:
Summary of Rules (from Instructions)

Gauntlet is a role-playing board game in which players (often referred to in their game role as Travelers) battle their way through a maze of hazardous tunnels and monsters.

Gauntlet may be played in four different versions: the Race Game, the Treasure Game, the Hunter Game, or the Tournament Game.  The object in each is to be the first player to have his or her traveler cross from one side of the board to the other.  When one player does, on the following turn the Gauntlet will begin to collapse, starting with the innermost square and proceeding outward by "rings" with each turn until the entire board has collapsed.  If no other players make it across the Gauntlet before the entire board has fallen, the first player wins the game.  If any other player makes it across to tie the first player, the tied player who has accumulated the most points wins the game.

Name: Fridolins Himmelsreise
Description:
An old game from the series "Fridolin-Spiele in der Tüte", cheap games in a paper bag instead of a box.

Obviously (there are board, dice and small airplanes in it) it`s a dice-rolling game for children, where each player has to move his airplane one round through the sky (its subtitle is: "Ein Wettfliegen durch die Sternenwelt", so it`s a race-game).

Name: Hit n' Run
Description: Simple game something like a pin ball machine. Ball is hit and goes into holes that represent hits, balls, strikes and outs. When that happens players move around the bases. Object is to score more runs than your opponent. Game comes with  base runners for both the red and the blue teams.

Name: Acronymity
Description: Guess the meaning of an acronym or abbreviation to advance around a board. First person/team to reach the ending space on the board and then answer a question correctly wins. Each game comes with 952 question cards in about 20 categories. Answering a question correctly without needing any hints allows you to roll a 4-5-6 die to determine your movement; if you needed a hint, you instead roll a 1-2-3 die.

Name: Le Avventure di Sherlock Holmes
Description:
The preparation of the game is limited to the allocation of the characters and the placement of tokens clue.
The characters represented are 6, Sherlock Holmes, Watson, Lestrade, Moriarty, Hudson and the couple Todd and Smiley, that those who remember the cartoon certainly recognize, and each have two cards, so you could find with two players represent the same character.

The course, as befits a children's play is very simple, and everyone in their turn will only turn the "roulette" and see which of the nine squares of the board will go to search for clues. Seven of these boxes are red and starting the game with three tokens clue places on them, a blue box used to have the 21 coins in excess, and the yellow box is the "waste".

When a player comes in a red box, to check whether one of the tokens present there is one depicting one of its special character, in which case he must take it and place it face down in front of him. If it finds the first token must then catch the blue box and keep it the same way ahead in case corresponds to their character, or discard it in the yellow box otherwise.

The game continues, until it is emptied a red box or blue box.
Then the player who drew the last coin, discovered the chips has previously collected (if it has, otherwise you go to the next player) and becomes the examination. The other at this point watching the chips and consulting support control, they must understand what the character looked, and as said before, who first guesses wins the game. If anyone guess, the player who collected more tokens, and in this case is virtually impossible to win the examiner, because even if he had collected a lot of chips, surely the many tokens collected would go to "unmask".

Name: Agilidade
Description:
Agilidade ... a 3-in-row game.

Material: glass game board, black and white wood playing pieces - 7 per player.

White starts and, in turn, pieces are placed on any one of 5 spaces, including on other pieces.
The object is to get 3 same-color pieces in a row - horizontally, vertically or diagonally.

Name: Robots
Description: Based on the animated film, players are robots moving around Robot City (the board) collecting spare parts tokens. Watch out for The Sweeper - he's a wind-up robot who runs in a grooved track in the board - if he touches you, you lose a token & go back to the last station.

Name: Pokémon Battle Dome
Description: A plastic dome covers an "arena" where energy balls are dispensed by a wind-up gizmo. Players use pinball-like flippers to keep energy balls from ending up in their scoring tray. (Gates are included with the game so that you can play with 2-4 players, even though there are four stations.)

Name: Who Am I?
Description:
"I was a Book of Mormon prophet who raised the Title of Liberty. Who Am I? I gathered the songs for the first hymnbook of the Church. Who Am I? I told people that a flood would cover the earth if they didn’t repent. Who Am I? Do you know the answers? If you do, raise your hand. If you don’t, you soon will with this fun new game for the whole family.
Four Games in One! Younger children will love playing the “Match Game.” Older kids will have fun with the “Fill in the Blank” or “Who Am I” games. Even adults can get in on the fun by acting out the answers in the “Guess Who I Am” game. No matter who you are, you’ll just love playing Who Am I?"

Name: Bataplouf
Description:
This unusual take on Snap or Pairs takes place in the bath 
Contents include; 25 waterproof playing cards, with 5 different fish character designs. Cut out models of the 5 fishy characters to float around and catch when a match is made 
Also includes a fishing net to dry the cards

Divide the waterproof playing cards between the players and float the 5 fish characters around in the tub. Proceed to play as you would do in 'snap'. When a match is made the first player to grab the matching floating fish (which will be swimming around the players) wins the pack of cards.

Ages 4+
